summary: This is a reply memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of a motion to suppress evidence obtained via a grand jury subpoena to the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP. The motion argues the government violated Maxwell's Fourth Amendment, Fifth Amendment, and due process rights by obtaining 90,000 pages of confidential material from her civil case without proper notice. It seeks suppression of this evidence and dismissal of perjury counts (Five and Six) derived from it.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, filing a motion to suppress evidence obtained from her civil litigation materials and seeking dismissal of perjury counts.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, signatory on the reply memorandum from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed on the reply memorandum from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, signatory on the certificate of service.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed on the reply memorandum from the Law Offices of Bobbi C. Sternheim.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Named partner of Boies Schiller Flexner LLP, the law firm that represented Virginia Giuffre in the civil case against Maxwell. The memo suggests he communicated with the government about the case.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: The plaintiff in the prior civil defamation case (Giuffre v. Maxwell) against Ghislaine Maxwell. Her lawsuit generated the depositions and materials subpoenaed by the government.

persons.name: Judge Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: Judge presiding over the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case for unsealing matters. The memo notes she is unaware the protective order was modified and has not unsealed most of the material.

persons.name: Chief Judge Colleen McMahon
persons.context: The judge who modified the protective order in the Giuffre case ex parte, allowing the government to subpoena Boies Schiller. The defense alleges she was misled by the government.

persons.name: Judge Robert W. Sweet
persons.context: Former judge presiding over the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case. He issued a pre-deposition order requiring Giuffre to disclose materials related to criminal investigations.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in passing as Maxwell's associate and subject of the broader investigation. The memo states the civil case was a 'proxy prosecution' of Epstein and Maxwell.

connections.description: Boies represented Virginia Giuffre in the civil defamation lawsuit against Maxwell. The defense alleges Boies Schiller acted as a state agent with the government to set a 'perjury trap' for Maxwell.
Giuffre was the plaintiff suing Maxwell for defamation. Maxwell's depositions in that case form the basis for the perjury counts in the criminal indictment.
Referred to as associates in the context of alleged trafficking and abuse. The civil case is described as a 'proxy prosecution' of both.
The defense alleges Boies Schiller met with government prosecutors, promised to send depositions, and collaborated to set a perjury trap for Maxwell, potentially making the firm a state agent.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's deposition was taken in the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case. She testified without invoking the Fifth Amendment, relying on the protective order.

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's second deposition in the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case. Testimony from this deposition is charged in Count 6 (perjury) of the indictment.

events.title: Meeting Between Boies Schiller and Government
events.description: A meeting between attorneys from Boies Schiller Flexner and federal prosecutors, documented in notes. The defense argues this shows the government was contemplating a perjury prosecution before Maxwell's depositions.

events.title: Filing of Reply Memorandum
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense files this reply memorandum in support of her motion to suppress evidence from Boies Schiller and dismiss perjury counts.

locations: Southern District of New York (court jurisdiction)
Denver, CO (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C. office)
New York, NY (Cohen & Gresser LLP and Bobbi C. Sternheim offices)
keyFacts: The government obtained approximately 90,000 pages of confidential material from the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner via a grand jury subpoena, related to the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case.

The defense argues the government violated Maxwell's rights by obtaining a modification of the civil protective order ex parte from Chief Judge McMahon without giving Maxwell notice or an opportunity to be heard.
Counts Five and Six of the indictment are perjury charges based on Maxwell's April and July 2016 depositions in the Giuffre civil case.
The defense alleges the government and Boies Schiller collaborated, with a meeting on February 29, 2016, showing the government contemplated a perjury prosecution before Maxwell was deposed.

The defense claims Giuffre's attorneys violated a court order by not disclosing materials related to criminal investigations before Maxwell's deposition, which would have led her to invoke the Fifth Amendment.
